channel.title: OnOptions
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Why Leaders and Workers Think Differently About Workplace Safety Risks
item.description: Safeguards on the job aren’t just about falls or broken equipment now. Employees worry about work’s impact on their mental well-being.

item.title: With the BLS Shuttered, You Might Get Jobs Data From Private Companies
item.description: With federal statistical agencies closed by the budget shutdown, several companies are crunching numbers to publish their own job creation, growth, an...

item.title: Move from reactive to proactive customer service
item.description: Customer experience is entering the sci-fi age: knowing and understanding customers on an individual level, providing personalized service, and dedica...

item.title: Manufacturing Companies Are Helping Employees With Child Care. Should Your Company Join Them?
item.description: It can cost a small fortune to put kids in child care while you work—plus there’s all the stresses of travel getting to the office.

item.title: GLP-1s are reshaping bodies and budgets
item.description: Michelle, a 42-year-old marketing executive, was scrolling through her grocery app when she saw the total: $87. A year ago, her weekly cart never dipp...

item.title: Apple Is Being Accused of Training Its AI Using Copyrighted Books
item.description: Two neuroscientists are suing Apple. It’s not the only tech company facing a lawsuit like this one.

item.title: Lay’s drastically rebrands after disturbing finding: 42% of consumers didn’t know they were made out of potatoes
item.description: New bags—matte-ified and designed to look like wood planks (like a potato crate)—will hold the chips with revamped ingredient lists.

item.title: How Job Applicants Use Hidden Coding to Dupe AI Analyzing Their Resumes

item.title: Former Syrian president Assad is video gaming in a luxury Moscow apartment: Report
item.description: Syria’s former President Bashar al-Assad, whose notoriously brutal rule over the country earned him the nickname “ The Butcher ,” was deposed in 2024 ...

item.title: Billionaire MacKenzie Scott doubles down on DEI with $42 million donation
item.description: In a signal to nonprofits and boardrooms, the Yield Giving philanthropist is backing diversity and equity with no‑strings grants—building on more than...

item.title: A 3-person policy non-profit that worked on California’s AI safety law is publicly accusing OpenAI of intimidation tactics
item.description: In a widely read post on social media, the general counsel of Encode said OpenAI used subpoenas and political muscle to intimidate the firm and to und...

item.title: Markets and crypto are down today. Why these stocks are an unusual exception
item.description: On Friday, shares of U.S. rare earth stocks rose after President Donald Trump accused China of strict export controls and threatened a “massive increa...

item.title: Trump claims China holding the world ‘hostage’ on rare earths is ‘especially inappropriate’ after Gaza peace deal
item.description: Markets had their hopes up on trade peace between China and the U.S. That was shattered on Friday.

item.title: The U.S. and South Korea need to salvage their tariff and investment agreement—for the sake of the alliance
item.description: Seoul and Washington must see disagreements on investment and immigration as an opportunity to fine-tune a trade agreement they can both tolerate.
